Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to plan and organize the 2017 NSF Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigator (PI) Meeting. This meeting convenes all PIs of the National Science Foundation CPS Program for the fifth time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place on November 13-14, 2017 in Alexandria, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agencies' representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-driven and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PIs, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the CPS researcher community gathers to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or future sponsors. The 2017 PI meeting will feature additional demonstrations to show the impact of CPS research. Finally, we expect to conduct discussions across the community on considerations and ideas to inspire CPS 2.0, and future collaborations with the Industrial Internet Consortium which includes multiple organizations transitioning CPS research into practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2017 CPS PI Meeting – Project Outcomes Report

The 2017 Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting marked the eighth annual gathering of over 533 CPS researchers, Government program directors, industry representatives, and other stakeholders who came together to discuss new and ongoing programs in CPS research being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies. The 2017 CPS PI Meeting was held on November 13 and 14, 2017 at the Hilton Alexandria Mark Center Hotel in Alexandria, VA.

This eighth annual two-day gathering of over 530 stakeholders comprising CPS researchers, Government program directors, industry representatives, non-profit organizations, FFRDCs, and others, came together to discuss new and ongoing programs in CPS research being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies. Over 270 PIs actively participated by presenting talks about accomplishments and challenges in their CPS research that span a diversity of technologies and application domains; identifying new, emerging problems, developments, and opportunities for research; showcasing their research results and accomplishments via posters, demonstrations, and videos; and interacting and networking to forge new collaborations with colleagues in academia, industry, and Federal agencies program managers, and other research organizations.

Highlights of the 2017 PI Meeting program featured a keynote by Dr. Missy Cummings (Duke University), one of the Navy’s first female pilots, who delivered a presentation from a unique theoretical and practical perspective to CPS on the topic of Managing Uncertainty Through Human-Computer Collaborations. A panel led by Dr. Stephen Thompson, National Program Leader at the National Institute of Food and Agriculture showcased selected projects funded by USDA/NIFA. The 2017 meeting was the first to program mini CPS workshops- eight in total – that were selected from many ideas submitted by our principal investigators, a Women and Under-Represented Minorities Special Interest Networking event, as well as a Birds of a Feather entitled, Towards the Internationalization of CPS, that focused awareness of international engagement opportunities in the area of CPS research.

 Following is a breakout of the participation metrics and artifacts collected:

 1. Actual Attendance Metrics:

  • Total number of actual attendees - 533
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees - 271
  • Total number of Government attendees - 38
  • Total number of women attendees - 70
  • Total number of industry attendees - 13
  • Total number of student attendees - 50
  • Total number of non-PI academics and Others - 24
  • Total number of project staff - 6
  • Total number of international attendees - 5
  • Private citizens - 2
  • Others - 9
  • No-shows 49

 2. Registration Metrics:

  • 547 total number of registrants (based on pre-meeting data collected), including:
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees - 333
  • Non-PI academics - 30
  • Government representatives - 50
  • Industry representatives - 7
  • International representatives - 5
  • Students - 54
  • Others (NSF-Retired, AIT) – 2

 3. Artifacts Metrics: The following artifacts were generated from the listing of 348 unique research grant awards for this meeting: 

  • 41 keynotes, invited talks, and R&D project presentations were introduced representing a broad range of disciplines have been archived
  • 437 project abstracts were submitted by PIs
  • 333 project posters were presented at the programmed poster session which is the largest number of entries for a CPS PI Meeting to date.
  • 103 project videos have been submitted
  • 28 unique demonstrations by respective PIs were presented "live" in real-time. (Down from 40 entries last year which was the largest number of entries to date.)

 All public artifacts, including speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers, have been disseminated to communities of interest via websites for the 2016 CPS PI Meeting that can be found at https://cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg17 . All program committee working documents are stored on the program committee’s private working group website at https://cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg17-pc . These websites are permanently archived on the CPS VO, a web portal, which is managed and operated by Vanderbilt University’s Institute for Software Integrated Systems with funding support from NSF.

Additionally, a “live” webcast of all presentations can be found on the public website at http://www.tvworldwide.com/events/nsf/171113/ .

 

 

.

 

  

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2019
Modified by: Frankie King
